			Hi all,

I'd like to compare NEAT with my (of course new and powerful)
neuro-evolution methods. I've worked with the Boolean function (4
inputs, 1 output) :

(A xor B) and (c xor d)

This function is interesting because (1) it's deceptive and (2) it's
modular (the xor is used twice).

I've tried to set-up NEAT (using the c++ source code) but it does not
lead to any good fitness. Can anybody with more experience than me
with NEAT try ? It should be quick for any "neat master" and it would
prevent me from drawing any false conclusion ...

If it works for you, I would be glad to know how. If not, any
explanation will be welcome. I know that novelty search would probably
work to overcome the deceptiveness but I need to compare with the
standard NEAT at this time.

Thanks,
-- 
Jean-Baptiste Mouret / Mandor
